<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 109]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 828, 109]]<|/det|>

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 702, 92]]<|/det|>
The isotope thorium-234 is radioactive. It emits \(\beta\) -particles as it decays.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 848, 138]]<|/det|>
The incomplete nuclide equation represents the decay of thorium-234 to an isotope protactinium (Pa).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 351, 168]]<|/det|>
Complete the equation.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 176, 616, 210]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{234}{90}\mathrm{Th}\longrightarrow \mathrm{}^{95}\mathrm{Pa} + \mathrm{}^{95}\mathrm{B}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 201, 876, 218]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 230, 146, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 229, 875, 265]]<|/det|>
Fig. 11.1 shows a beam of \(\beta\) -particles from a sample of thorium-234 passing into the electric field between two charged plates in a vacuum.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 280, 682, 413]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 434, 515, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 11.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 465, 180, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 464, 875, 500]]<|/det|>
By drawing on Fig. 11.1, show how the \(\beta\) -particles move as they pass between the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 479, 875, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 504, 181, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 562, 523]]<|/det|>
Explain why the \(\beta\) -particles move in this way.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 597, 876, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]
